Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Secure Computing using Pluggable Trust Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the restoration of trust in computing systems. Successful cyberattacks, including mass privacy breaches and the discovery of device backdoors, have shaken trust in computing, put users at risk, hurt the economy, and even threatened our national security. The usual set of ad-hoc, incomplete, and costly approaches simply have not addressed the problem. This research effort will advance a viable, practical, and holistic solution that gives users much stronger guarantees of security while lowering the costs of keeping systems secure.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop TigerGuard, a computer system security architecture that contains the effects of cyberattacks on existing computer infrastructure. TrustGuard is based on a small, separately manufactured, and easy-to-verify hardware element, called the Sentry, that serves as the root of trust. The Sentry is a general-purpose hardware trust component that, when combined with an application-specific Dynamic Specification Check (DSC) software component, provides flexible containment capabilities. The containment guarantees of TigerGuard hold despite design and manufacturing flaws (known and not-yet-known, malicious and unintentional) in the operating system, firmware, hardware, and software, including those in the application software itself. Formal verification of both the Sentry and DSC, a practical effort given their total size of only a few thousand lines of code, becomes equivalent in security guarantees to proving hundreds of millions of existing lines of code correct (including the processor design, memory implementation, hard drive firmware, the operating system, shared libraries, and the application code).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to do the research and development necessary to bring strong containment-architecture computer security to the marketplace. Dozens of CTO, CIO, and CISO interviews revealed a near universal need for better security and management of laptops and desktops. They explained that, despite many products designed to address these needs, managing and securing employee laptops and desktops (i.e., endpoints) remained their top pain points. Using insight from these interviews, during the performance of this SBIR grant, Tigerstone developed a minimum viable product to address these needs. This product gives IT staff, for the first time, complete control and visibility of endpoints while also providing secure containment of insecure operating systems and user activities. The product does this regardless of the endpoint’s physical location and network used (even if insecure). The product uses virtualization to lock down the OS and observe it from the outside, offering new exploit prevention and detection capabilities. Virtualization also provides instant online exploit and system failure recovery while retaining a timeline of snapshots to support offline forensics.

More broadly, a product of this type can change the way people think about computation in much the same way that cloud services have done. It can change the computing experience by bringing new types of sharing, portability, and collaboration for all users of computing.
